content: The Act may be cited as the "Coptic Churches Accountability Act". In August 2013, Islamist-led mobs burned and destroyed Christian properties in Egypt after the government led by the Muslim Brotherhood was removed. The succeeding government, under President Sisi, announced that the army would rebuild the damaged churches at government expense. President Sisi, as the Minister of Defense of Egypt, ordered the armed forces to repair affected churches after sectarian violence in August 2013. In January 2015, he attended a Coptic Christian Christmas liturgy, and in 2016, he spoke at St. Mark's Cathedral in Cairo, acknowledging the past violence. President Sisi, during the Christmas liturgy at St. Mark's Cathedral in Cairo in January 2016, promised to restore all churches damaged in the 2013 sectarian violence. The Egyptian military has already restored 26 out of the 78 affected churches. Egyptian military has restored 26 out of 78 churches damaged in 2013 sectarian violence. Private citizens have also restored 23 buildings. 29 buildings in 24 locations still need restoration. New law in Egypt imposes burdens on church construction. 24 locations still need restoration as of September 6, 2016, due to a new law in Egypt imposing burdens on church construction, which has led to sectarian violence targeting Christians. In El-`Our, Minya, villagers protested the building of a new church approved by President Sisi in honor of Egyptian Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants in Libya in February 2015. Protestors armed with Molotov cocktails besieged the existing village church, setting it on fire. Protestors armed with Molotov cocktails besieged the existing village church, throwing bricks at another Christian's house and setting fire to a Christian-owned vehicle. Egyptian government officials engage in reconciliation sessions to address sectarian violence, but outcomes are disputed by human rights groups. The Coptic Christians in Egypt have been the indigenous people for over 2,000 years and represent the largest Christian community in the Middle East. United States diplomatic leadership contributes to the international protection of religious minorities and their faith-based practices. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 emphasizes the importance of condemning violations of religious freedom and promoting this fundamental right. Religious freedom is crucial for democracy, individual liberty, and stability, and the United States prioritizes promoting this value in its interactions with other countries. The International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 emphasizes the importance of promoting religious freedom as a fundamental right. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of State must provide a report on the progress of restoring Christian religious properties in Egypt after the 2013 sectarian violence to the relevant congressional committees every year until 2021. The report must include details on the restoration or repair of Christian religious properties and properties owned by Christians in Egypt after the 2013 sectarian violence, discussions between Department of State officials and Egyptian representatives, the implementation of laws for constructing Christian churches, and the nature of Egyptian laws and policies. The report must include details on the restoration or repair of Christian religious properties and properties owned by Christians in Egypt after the 2013 sectarian violence, discussions between Department of State officials and Egyptian representatives, the implementation of laws for constructing Christian churches, and the nature and extent of Egyptian laws and policies regarding the construction of Christian churches or places of worship. The Secretary of State will ensure that each Country Report on Human Rights Practices for Egypt includes information on the number of permits issued for the construction of Christian churches. The Secretary of State will ensure that each Country Report on Human Rights Practices for Egypt includes a summary of information on Christian churches, places of worship, and other religious properties, as well as a list of these properties.
